1 OCTOBER: 1 OCTOBER BIBLE LESSON 1 Samuel 24:16 LESSON Saul's tears VERSE 16 And it came to pass, when David had made an end of speaking these words unto Saul, that Saul said, Is this thy voice, my son David? And Saul lifted up his voice, and wept. Saul had lived under the delusion that David was out to get him, but David's refusal to kill him when he had the chance proved beyond doubt that this was false. David's obedience to God and his sincerity softened Saul's heart. Saul now spoke tenderly and addressed David as "my son", in response to the son-in-law who earlier called him "my father" [v. 11]. Affected by David's kindness, relieved at being spared certain death, and feeling guilty about his own viciousness, Saul lifted up his voice and wept. Saul's remorse was evidently genuine, but was it true repentance? From his subsequent actions, we know it was not. It did not "bring forth fruits meet for repentance" [Matthew 3:8]. True repentance entails a resolve to cease the wrongful conduct, and replace it with godly living. Where the sin is against an individual, amends must be made to that person. Where possible, an attempt at restitution should be made. A good example is seen in the case of Zacchaeus [Luke 19:8]. Saul's reaction is simply that of a man whose God-given conscience has been pricked. His tears could also be for the misery he had brought on himself through his vindictiveness and jealousy. The example of Saul must cause us to examine our own response to the sacrificial death of our Lord Jesus Christ for us, when we were yet without strength [Romans 5:6], and enemies of God [Romans 5:10]. While it is true that there is nothing we can do to save ourselves, repentance - as the Westminster Confession of Faith says - is evangelical grace and a corollary of our salvation, because faith without works is dead [James 2:17]. 3 OCTOBER: 3 OCTOBER BIBLE LESSON 1 Samuel 24:20-22 LESSON Saul's submission to God's will VERSE 20 And now, behold, I know well that thou shalt surely be king, and that the kingdom of Israel shall be established in thine hand. Having confessed his own wrongdoings and acknowledged David to be "more righteous", King Saul finally accepted the reality that the Lord had rent the kingdom from him, and given it to a neighbour that was better than he [1 Samuel 15:28]. He therefore made David swear he would not cut off his seed after him. In ancient times, it was common practice for a new king to kill all the descendants of the ruler whom he replaced. This prevented them from rising up and re-establishing the dead king's dynasty. Such atrocity happened even in Israel during the time of the Judges [Judges 9:5] and the Kings [2 Chronicles 22:10]. David had already promised Jonathan that he would not kill his descendants [1 Samuel 20:14-17], and here, he made the same promise to Saul. Thus, they parted in peace, David being reassured of God's promotion, and Saul resigned to God's sacking. Saul's concern is similar to that of Joseph's brothers who were afraid that Joseph would take revenge on them once their father died [Genesis 50:15]. Like Joseph, David too must have asked himself, "Am I in the place of God?" [Genesis 50:19]. Today's reading reminds us that the Sovereign God "ruleth in the kingdom of men, and giveth it to whomsoever He will" [Daniel 4:32]. Regardless of the political party that comes to power in any country, we should confess like King Nebuchadnezzar, who "praise and extol and honour the King of heaven, all Whose works are truth, and His ways judgement" [Daniel 4:37a]. THOUGHT Obedience to the will of God gives you wings, not chains! - Warren Wiersbe TO COMPLETE THE BIBLE IN 2 YEARS, READ DANIEL 11 MATTHEW 3
